1 Introduction

LingTree is a tool to produce linguistic tree diagrams. The user keys in a description of the tree, processes that description, and LingTree shows what the tree looks like. The tree can be saved in a number of different file formats so that it can be included in papers or web pages.

LingTree looks like what is shown in (1).

(1)

One keys the description in the top pane, processes the description, and then the tree appears in the bottom pane. See section 2 for information on keying a tree description and processing a tree.

You can drag the edges of the window to make it larger. You can also drag the bar between the panes to make either the tree display or the description larger (or smaller).

2 Editing a Tree Description

You key in a tree description in the top pane. To show the corresponding tree in the bottom pane, you "process" the description in any one of three ways:

  • by clicking the "process the tree description button" ()
  • by clicking on the Tree menu item and then Process Description
  • or by typing CTRL-D (holding the CTRL key down while pressing the D key).

All three do the same processing and are equivalent in effect.

2.1 Basic Tree Description

A tree description consists of a set of nodes enclosed within parentheses. The parentheses may be nested according to the tree structure. Whenever you key a closing parenthesis ')', the matching opening parenthesis will be selected briefly. This is to help you match nested opening and closing parentheses.

Here are two examples of how to key trees.

When you key what is in (2), it shows up as in (3).

(2)
(S (NP) (VP))
(3)

And if you key what is in (4)

(4)
(S (NP (Lee)) (VP (V (gets)) (NP (Det (the)) (N (idea)))))

it will produce what is in (5)

(5)

You may set the fonts for the nodes. See section 3, especially 3.2.

2.2 Handling Parentheses

If you need to put an opening or closing parenthesis in your tree, quote the parenthesis by using a backslash immediately before it. For example, if you key what is in (6)

(6)
(NP (Paul \(the bear\)))

it will come out as in

(7)

If you do not quote the parentheses with a backslash, then it will look like what is in (8).

(8)

2.3 Indicating a Lexical Item

To mark a node in the tree as a lexical item, key \L before it (i.e. right after the opening parenthesis). Note that it is important to include a space between the \L and the lexical item that follows it. For example, suppose we have set the parameters so that lexical items come out in red (see section 3, especially 3.2). Then keying what is in (9)

(9)
(S (NP (\L John)) (VP (V (\L sleeps))))

will produce what is in (10).

(10)

Also, notice that in the description, the lexical items are also shown in red.

If you do not key the \L, then it will look like what is in (11).

(11)

2.4 Indicating a Gloss Item

To mark a node in the tree as a gloss item, key \G before it (i.e. right after the opening parenthesis). Note that it is important to include a space between the \G and the gloss item that follows it. If one is going to mark glosses, one should also mark lexical items. For example, suppose we have set the parameters so that lexical items come out in red and gloss items come out in blue (see section 3, especially 3.2). Then keying what is in (12)

(12)
(S (NP (\L Juan (\G John))) (VP (V (\L duerme (\G sleeps)))))

produces what is in (13).

(13)

Notice that there are no lines between the lexical items and their respective glosses and that the glosses are relatively close to the lexical item. In addition the colors also show up in the description box.

If you do not key the \G , then it would look like what is in (14).

(14)

Notice that there is greater space between the lexical items and their glosses. The blue color also does not show for the gloss items.

2.5 Indicating a Triangle (a phrase)

To mark a node as a phrase by using a triangle above it, key \T before it (i.e. right after the opening parenthesis). Note that it is important to include a space between the \T and whatever follows it. For example, keying what is in (15)

(15)
(NP (\T all the King’s men))

will produce what is in (16).

(16)

If you do not key the \T, then it will look like what is in (17).

(17)

You may key both a triangle and either a lexical item or a gloss for a given node. The order in which you key the \T and either the \L or the \G does not matter. Either order will work. You just need to be sure to include a space after each one.

Note that if you use the “Flat” option (see section 3.3) while using triangles, you will need to also use either the \L or the \G at the same time. Otherwise, the triangle node may not be at the same level as other “flattened” nodes.

2.6 Omitting a Line

To not have a line show above a node, key \O before it (i.e. right after the opening parenthesis). Note that it is important to include a space between the \O and whatever follows it. For example, keying what is in (18)

(18)
((\O σ (O (\L t)) (N (R (\L e)))) (\O σ (O (\L p)) (N (R (\L i)) (C (\L k)))))

will produce what is in (19) (assuming that the "flat" structure parameter is also chosen; see 3.3).

(19)

If you do not key the \Os, then it will look like what is in (20).

(20)

You may combine the omit lines command with either a lexical item or a gloss for a given node. The order in which you key the \O and either the \L or the \G does not matter. Either order will work. You just need to be sure to include a space after each one.

2.7 Indicating Subscripts or Superscripts

One can include simple subscripts and superscripts within a tree node.

2.7.1 Subscript

To have a subscript show up at the end of some text, key /s before the subscript text. Note that this has a forward slash, not a backslash. It also uses a lowercase s, not uppercase (uppercase is used for a superscript). One does not have to include a space between the /s and whatever follows it. For example, keying what is in (21)

(21)
(S (NP/s1 (N (dogs))) (VP (V (chase)) (NP/s2 (N (cats)))))

will produce what is in (22).

(22)

If you do not key the /s, then it will look like what is in (23).

(23)

2.7.2 Superscript

To have a superscript show up at the end of some text, key /S before the superscript text. Note that this has a forward slash, not a backslash. It also uses a uppercase S, not lowercase (lowercase is used for a subscript). One does not have to include a space between the /S and whatever follows it. For example, keying what is in (24)

(24)
(IP (DP) (I/S'))

will produce what is in (25).

(25)

If you do not key the /S, then it will look like what is in (26).

(26)

2.7.3 Combining Subscripts and Superscripts does not Work

Currently, you may not combine both subscripts and superscripts. Once either a subscript or a superscript is indicated, the rest of the text of the node will be treated as either a subscript or a superscript.

3 Modifying the Tree Parameters

One can adjust the positioning of the tree and its nodes as well as choose the fonts, sizes, and colors for the non-terminal, lexical item, and gloss nodes. One can also set a background color and determine the color and thickness of the lines in the trees. In addition, one can have the tree show all of its lexical and gloss items at the same vertical position.

To set any of these parameters, invoke the Tree Parameters dialog box (Click on the Tree menu item and then click on Parameters...). The dialog box looks like what is shown in (27)

(27)

3.1 Setting the (X, Y) Parameters

The (X,Y) Parameters section allows you to determine the initial upper-left position of the tree (Leftmost X-coordinate and Topmost Y-coordinate) and to set the gap between the nodes (Horizontal gap between terminal nodes and Vertical gap between nodes). The units are in 0.01 millimeters. The Gap adjustment between Lex and Gloss allows you to fine-tune the vertical gap between lexical and gloss items. You can use negative numbers for any of these values (but you may not always like the results).

3.2 Setting the Font Information

The fonts section allows you to change the font, face, size, and color for the non-terminal, lexical item and gloss nodes. Click on the appropriate button. You can also set the color of the background, the color of the lines, and the thickness of the lines. On the latter, there is a minimum size; if what you set is too small, the minimum will still be used. You need to set it to at least 40 before you will notice any difference.

3.2.1 Try to Smooth Slanted Lines

If you check the “Try to smooth slanted lines” checkbox, it will attempt to smooth out some of the jaggedness in the slanted lines. For example, without this box checked, (28) would appear as in (29).

(28)
(IP (NP (Det (\L n (\G the))) (N' (N (\L Juan (\G John))))) (I' (I0) (VP (V' (V (\L kita (\G sees))) (NP (Det (\L n (\G the))) (N' (N (\L koatl (\G snake)))))))))
(29)

With it checked, however, it looks like (30).

(30)

If you also check the “Also try to enhance the smoothing of slanted lines” checkbox, it will look like (31).

(31)

3.3 Showing "Flat" Trees

The Show flat view of lexical and gloss items check box will control how the lexical and gloss items are displayed.

For example, without the box checked, the description in (32)

(32)
(IP (NP (Det (\L n (\G the))) (N' (N (\L Juan (\G John))))) (I' (I0) (VP (V' (V (\L kita (\G sees))) (NP (Det (\L n (\G the))) (N' (N (\L koatl (\G snake)))))))))

will appear as in (33).

(33)

With the box checked, however, it will look like the tree in (34).

(34)

3.4 Setting the Default Set of Parameters

The Use these parameters as the default for new trees check box allows you to have LingTree remember your parameter settings for other trees that you build.

4 Saving the Tree

While the resulting tree looks nice within the LingTree program, what one usually wants to do is to embed the tree in some other document. LingTree allows you to save the tree in any one of seven formats:

  • A Windows bitmap (*.bmp) file.
  • A Windows Enhanced Metafile (*.emf) file.
  • A Graphics Interchange Format (*.gif) file.[1]
  • A JPEG File Interchange Format (*.jpg) file.
  • A Portable Network Graphics (*.png) file.
  • A Tagged Image File format (*.tif) file.
  • Scalable Vector Graphics format (*.svg) file.

You select which of these formats you wish to save by clicking on the File menu item and then clicking on the Set Save Formats... item. This calls up the Set Save Formats dialog box which looks like what is shown in (35).

(35)

You merely check all the formats you wish to use. LingTree will produce a file with the given extension for each checked format. The file name (i.e. the part before the extension) is the same for all of them.

In addition, you will find a file with an extension of ".tre" which contains information for LingTree to draw the tree. Do not edit this file.

Note that once you set these Save Formats, they stay in effect for all ensuing trees you build.

5 Known problems

The following items are known to be less than desirable with this version of LingTree:

  • There is currently no way to key or display both a subscript and a superscript within a single node. One can key and display simple subscripts or simple superscripts, but not both in the same node. Also, it is not possible to key either a subscript or a superscript within the middle of the text of a node; once either a subscript or superscript is started, the rest of the text in that node will be either subscript or superscript.
  • There is currently no way to either key or display italic, bold, or underscore for parts of a given node. One can, however, have all nodes of a given type display in italic or bold or be underscored. See section 3, especially 3.2.
  • The Edit / Undo and Edit / Redo menu items and keyboard shortcuts do not currently work.
